If you are creating your own server on here, don't use a domain name with the word "mastodon".

The word "mastodon" in relation to social networks is a registered trademark owned by Eugen Rochko's Mastodon gGmbH organisation.

If you use a domain name which includes the word "mastodon", you can be sued by Eugen's organisation if you don't comply with their terms:

https://joinmastodon.org/trademark

For example, this would potentially make it illegal to switch to software unapproved by Mastodon gGmbH.

My response to NIH's RFI for their Open Access Policy: https://jon-e.net/blog/2023/04/24/Re-NIH-RFI-OSTP-Memo/

tl;dr: #APCs are fundamentally inequitable, and it's about the infrastructure, the infrastructure, the infrastructure.

"If this proposal leaves the for-profit publishing apparatus largely intact, it will enter the history of half-measures made in deference to the publishing oligopoly that leave the problem perpetually unsolved. What could the world be like if we had 20 years of experimenting with open research dissemination, rather than spending the dawn of the information era hobbled by broken systems accessible to a vanishingly small and privileged few? Will we be looking back in another 20 years wishing we had the courage to end for-profit publishing now?"

The paper "Shall We Really Do It Again?" by Schmidt from 2009 is still on of the best papers discussing replication studies in the social sciences, with a good overview of different types and functions. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0015108 I highly recommend reading it - the well-meant advice not to conduct replication studies when you are dependent upon publications, and the hope this will change in the next decades, is an especially nice reminder of how far we have come!

last_post.content:
Did you know there are hundreds of indie food delivery platforms?

But why do people choose indies over DoorDash or Uber Eats?

Because it gives people more 🌟 agency 🌟 and because its infrastructure embraces 🔨 humans doing repair work.

Our collaborator @samanthadalal led this study of dozens of couriers, restaurateurs, customers and platform staff of an indie platform in Colorado.

title: 10 Tips on Writing the Living Web

last_post.content:
Many folks are asking (again) why write online. I often return to this 2002 Mark Bernstein essay.

As a student, I was blown away by the idea of coffee with writers you like. I remember thinking "you can do that?" That's how I started imagining myself in a community of writing/ideas.

Write:
- for a reason
- often
- tight

And:
- make good friends
- find good enemies
- let the story unfold
- stand up, speak out
- be sexy (ok, I fail this one)
- use your archives
- relax

https://alistapart.com/article/writeliving/

"In his excellent book on #surveillance, Bruce Schneier has pointed out we would never agree to carry tracking devices and report all our most intimate conversations if the government made us do it.

But under such a scheme, we would enjoy more legal protections than we have now. By letting ourselves be tracked voluntarily, we forfeit all protection against how that information is used.

Those who control the data gain enormous power over those who don't."

title: Physical Attractiveness Bias in the Legal System — The Law Project

last_post.content:
"When I started looking into this subject, I predicted a person’s physical attractiveness would only have minor advantages. I was wrong. […] I was so wrong."

Makes you wonder how this plays out in other industries 🙃

https://www.thelawproject.com.au/insights/attractiveness-bias-in-the-legal-system

The "paradox of robustness" is that if the system evolves to tolerate failures in X, the expected effect over time is reduced performance of X,

e.g., develop RAID to tolerate hard-disk failures, and this just encourages the use of cheaper lower-performing disks

Or introduce chaperones to refold proteins after a heat-shock, and this opens an evolutionary door for proteins in general to lose intrinsic stability (even at normal temps)

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09069
